(host, 1992–2009, 2010–2014)
''[[The Jay Leno Show]]''
(host, 2009–2010) }} '''James Douglas Muir Leno''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|l|ɛ|n|oʊ}}; born April 28, 1950){{cite news|url = https://movies.nytimes.com/person/1548610/Jay-Leno/biography|title = Jay Leno Biography|accessdate = February 3, 2009|work = [[The New York Times]]}} is an American comedian, actor, writer, producer, and television host. After doing stand-up comedy for years, he became the host of [[NBC]]'s ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'' from 1992 to 2009. Beginning in September 2009, Leno started a primetime talk show, titled ''[[The Jay Leno Show]]'', which aired weeknights at 10:00 p.m. [[Eastern Time|ET]], also on NBC. After ''The Jay Leno Show'' was canceled in January 2010 amid a [[2010 Tonight Show conflict|host controversy]], Leno returned to host ''The Tonight Show with Jay Leno'' on March 1, 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.thewrap.com/ind-column/new-nbc-breaking-story-13241 |title=Exclusive: Conan, NBC Officially Splitsville (Updated) |first=Josef |last=Adalian |date=January 21, 2010 |work=The Wrap |accessdate=January 21, 2010 }} He hosted his last episode of ''The Tonight Show'' on February 6, 2014. That year, he was inducted into the [[Television Hall of Fame]].{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/12/julia-louis-dreyfus-david-e-kelley-jay-leno-rupert-murdoch-ray-dolby-brandon-stoddard-named-to-tv-academys-hall-of-fame/|title=Julia Louis-Dreyfus, David E. Kelley, Jay Leno, Rupert Murdoch, Ray Dolby, Brandon Stoddard Named To TV Academy's Hall of Fame|work=Deadline.com|last=The Deadline Team|date=December 16, 2013|accessdate=February 22, 2014}} ==Early life== Leno was born April 28, 1950 in [[New Rochelle, New York|New Rochelle]], New York. His homemaker mother, Catherine (née Muir; 1911–1993), was born in [[Greenock]], Scotland, and came to the United States at age 11. His father, Angelo (1910–1994), was an insurance salesman who was born in New York, to immigrants from [[Flumeri]], Italy.{{cite web|accessdate=May 11, 2008|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/70/Jay-Leno.html|title=Jay Leno Biography (1950–)|publisher=Film Reference}} Leno grew up in [[Andover, Massachusetts]], and graduated from [[Andover High School (Massachusetts)|Andover High School]]."Andover Biography-- Jay Leno." Memorial Hall Library Andover (MA). [http://answers.mhl.org/Andover_Biography_-_Jay_Leno]. Leno obtained a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[speech therapy]] from [[Emerson College]], where he started a comedy club in 1973. His older brother, Patrick (May 12, 1940 – October 6, 2002),{{cite web|url=http://www.ancientfaces.com/person/patrick-leno/13503472|title=Patrick Leno|work=AncientFaces}} was a [[Vietnam War]] veteran who worked as an attorney. ==Career== ===Early career=== Leno made his first appearance on ''The Tonight Show'' on March 2, 1977, performing a comedy routine.{{YouTube|rxmXpzcl4MI|Jay Leno's First Appearance on the Tonight Show}} March 2, 1977. Retrieved June 28, 2013.[http://www.nbc.com/the-tonight-show/about/bio/cast/jay-leno/587494/ Jay Leno Bio] NBC. Retrieved June 28, 2013. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130216110040/http://www.nbc.com/the-tonight-show/about/bio/cast/jay-leno/587494/ |date=February 16, 2013 }} During the 1970s, Leno appeared in minor roles in several television series and films, first in the 1976 episode "J.J. in Trouble" of ''[[Good Times]]'' and the same year in the pilot of ''[[Holmes & Yo-Yo]]''. After an uncredited appearance in the 1977 film ''[[Fun with Dick and Jane (1977 film)|Fun with Dick and Jane]]'', he played more prominent roles in 1978 in ''[[American Hot Wax]]'' and ''[[Silver Bears]]''. Other films and television series from that period include ''Almost Heaven'' (1978), "Going Nowhere" (1979) from ''[[One Day at a Time]]'', ''[[Americathon]]'' (1979), ''[[Polyester (film)|Polyester]]'' (1981), "The Wild One" (1981) from ''[[Alice (TV series)|Alice]]'', and both "Feminine Mistake" (1979) and "Do the Carmine" (1983) from ''[[Laverne & Shirley]]''. Leno's only starring film role was the 1989 direct-to-video ''[[Collision Course (1989 film)|Collision Course]]'', opposite [[Pat Morita]]. He also appeared numerous times on ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]''. ===''The Tonight Show''=== [[File:Jay Leno (1993) by Alan Light.jpg|thumb|upright|right|200px|Leno in 1993, in the year after becoming host of ''The Tonight Show'']] Starting in 1987, Leno was a regular substitute host for [[Johnny Carson]] on ''[[The Tonight Show]]''. In 1992, he replaced Carson as host{{cite news|title=Carson cuts appearances|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NQMIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=SzYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5008,192179&dq=tonight+jay-leno+shandling|agency=Associated Press|work=Rome News-Tribune|location=Rome, Ga.|page=14|date=June 2, 1987|accessdate=October 26, 2008}} amid controversy with [[David Letterman]], who had been hosting ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]'' since 1982 (aired after ''The Tonight Show''), and whom many—including Carson himself—had expected to be Carson's successor. The story of this turbulent transition was later turned into [[The Late Shift (book)|a book]] and [[The Late Shift (film)|a movie]]. Leno continued to perform as a stand-up comedian throughout his tenure on ''The Tonight Show''. In 2004, Leno signed a contract extension with [[NBC]] which would keep him as host of ''The Tonight Show'' until 2009.{{cite news|title=NBC signs Jay Leno to contract extension|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-03-30-leno-contract-extended_x.htm |agency=Associated Press|work=USA Today|date=March 31, 2004|accessdate=October 26, 2008}} Later in 2004, [[Conan O'Brien]] signed a contract with NBC under which O'Brien would become the host of ''The Tonight Show'' in 2009, replacing Leno at that time.{{cite news|first=Bill|last=Carter|title=Conan O'Brien to Succeed Jay Leno in 2009, NBC Announces|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/27/business/media/28CND-NBC.html?pagewanted=print&position= |work=The New York Times|date=September 27, 2004|accessdate=October 26, 2008}} During the [[2007–08 Writers Guild of America strike]], Leno was accused of violating WGA guidelines by writing his own monologue for ''The Tonight Show''. While NBC and Leno claim there were private meetings with the WGA where there was a secret agreement allowing this, the WGA denied such a meeting.{{cite web|accessdate=May 11, 2008|url=http://www.deadlinehollywooddaily.com/lenowga-whats-the-real-story-nbc-claims-jay-asked-for-received-wga-permission-to-write-monologue-at-monday-meeting-with-verrone-et-al/|title=LENO/WGA: WHAT'S THE REAL STORY? NBC Claims Jay Asked For & Received WGA Permission To Write Monologue At Secret Monday Meeting With Verrone|publisher=Deadline Hollywood Daily}} Leno answered questions in front of the [[Writers Guild of America, West]] trial committee in February 2009 and June 2009, and when the WGAW published its list of strike-breakers on August 11, 2009, Leno was not on the list.{{cite news | url = http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/entertainmentnewsbuzz/2009/08/guild-clears-jay-leno-of-violating-strike-rules.html | title = WGA: No chin music for Jay Leno | work = Company Town | first = Richard | last = Verrier | publisher = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date = August 11, 2009 | accessdate = August 14, 2009 }}{{cite news | url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118007189.html?categoryId=2821&cs=1 | title = Jay Leno cleared of strike violations; WGA West issues penalties in three cases | first = Cynthia | last = Littleton | date = August 11, 2009 | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | location = New York City | publisher = [[Reed Business Information]] | accessdate = August 14, 2009 }} Leno said in 2008 that he was saving all of his income from ''The Tonight Show'' and living solely off his income from stand-up comedy.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2008-07-16-leno-cover_N.htm|title=Jay Leno Gears up for Life After 'Tonight'|last=della Cava|first=Marco|date=July 17, 2008|work=USA Today|accessdate=April 25, 2009}} On April 23, 2009, Leno checked himself into a hospital with an undisclosed illness.{{cite news | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/TV/04/23/leno.hospitalized/index.html | title = Jay Leno hospitalized; 'Tonight Show' tapings canceled | first = Jack | last = Hannah | work = [[CNN.com]] | date = April 23, 2009 | publisher = [[Cable News Network]] | accessdate = August 14, 2009 }} He was released the following day and returned to work on Monday, April 27. The two subsequently cancelled ''Tonight Show'' episodes for April 23 and 24 were Leno's first in 17 years as host.{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/2009/04/24/2009-04-24_rep_jay_leno_hospital_trip_precautionary_late_night_host_to_be_released_friday.html|title=Jay Leno released from the hospital|publisher=NYDailyNews|accessdate=April 24, 2009 | location=New York | first=Nancy | last=Dillon | date=April 24, 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.canada.com/News/Leno+misses+first+show+years/1530668/story.html |title=Jay Leno misses first show in 17 years |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=April 24, 2009 |work=[[Canada.com]] |publisher=[[Canwest Publishing Inc.]] |location=[[Winnipeg]], Manitoba |accessdate=August 14, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Initially, the illness that caused the absence was not disclosed, but later Leno told People magazine that the ailment was exhaustion.{{cite news | url = http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20276256,00.html | title = Jay Leno Reveals Mystery Ailment: Exhaustion | date = May 1, 2009 | work = [[People.com]] | first = Pamela | last = Warrick | publisher = [[Time Inc.]] | accessdate = August 14, 2009 }} ====Michael Jackson trial==== During the [[Trial of Michael Jackson|2005 trial of Michael Jackson]] over allegations of child molestation, Leno was one of a few celebrities who appeared as a defense witness. In his testimony regarding a call by the accuser, Leno testified that he never called the police, that no money was asked for, and there was no coaching – but that the calls seemed unusual and scripted.{{cite web|accessdate=May 11, 2008|url=http://www.courttv.com/trials/jackson/052405_ctv.html|title=Comedians Jay Leno and Chris Tucker testify for Michael Jackson|publisher=[[Court TV]]|date=May 24, 2005|author=Sweetingham, Lisa |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080315195750/http://www.courttv.com/trials/jackson/052405_ctv.html |archivedate= March 15, 2008}} [[File:JayLeno.jpg|thumb|right|Leno in 2006]] As a result, Leno was initially not allowed to tell jokes about Jackson or the case, which had been a fixture of ''The Tonight Show''{{'}}s opening monologue in particular. But he and his show's writers used a legal loophole by having Leno briefly step aside while stand-in comedians took the stage and told jokes about the trial. Stand-ins included [[Roseanne Barr]], [[Drew Carey]], [[Brad Garrett]], and [[Dennis Miller]], among others.{{cite episode|accessdate=May 11, 2008|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0503/08/sbt.01.html|title=Nemcova Speaks Out on Surviving Tsunami; Michael Jackson`s Trial Continues; Interview With Kevin Costner |series=[[Showbiz Tonight]]|publisher=CNN|airdate=March 8, 2005|first=Karyn|last=Bryant}} The gag order was challenged, and the court ruled that Leno could continue telling jokes about the trial as long as he did not discuss his testimony. Leno celebrated by devoting an entire monologue to Michael Jackson jokes. ===Succession by Conan O'Brien and ''The Jay Leno Show''=== {{Main article|The Jay Leno Show}} Because Leno's show continued to lead all late-night programming in the [[Nielsen ratings]], the pending expiration of Leno's contract led to speculation about whether he would become a late-night host for another network after his commitment to NBC expired.{{cite news|first=Frazier |last=Moore |title=NBC's Jay Leno-Conan O'Brien swap prompts rumors |url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/fanfare/nbc-s-jay-leno-conan-o-brien-swap-prompts-rumors-1.881678 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131216165209/http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/fanfare/nbc-s-jay-leno-conan-o-brien-swap-prompts-rumors-1.881678 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 16, 2013 |agency=Associated Press |work=Newsday |date=May 14, 2008 |accessdate=June 28, 2013 }} Leno left ''The Tonight Show'' on Friday, May 29, 2009,{{cite news|first=Bill|last=Carter|title=Date Is Set for Leno's 'Tonight' Finale|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/22/arts/television/22late.html?n=Top/Reference/Times%20Topics/Subjects/T/Television|work=The New York Times|date=July 22, 2008|accessdate=October 26, 2008}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/30/arts/television/30leno.html?em|title=Jay Leno Takes Final Bow on 'Tonight Show' |date=May 30, 2009|work=The New York Times|accessdate=May 30, 2009 | first=Bill | last=Carter}} and Conan O'Brien took over on June 1, 2009. On December 8, 2008, it was reported that Leno would remain on NBC and move to a new hour-long show at 10 p.m. Eastern Time (9 p.m. Central Time) five nights a week.{{cite news|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/09/business/media/09leno.html?em|title = Where Is Leno Going? To Prime Time, on NBC | work=The New York Times | first=Bill | last=Carter | date=December 9, 2008 | accessdate=May 6, 2010}} This show followed a similar format to ''The Tonight Show'', was filmed in the same studio facility and retained many of Leno's most popular segments. ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien|Late Night]]'' host [[Conan O'Brien]] was his successor on ''The Tonight Show''.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/SHOWBIZ/TV/07/21/tv.nbc.tonight.ap/index.html|title=Leno's last 'Tonight' announced|accessdate=July 21, 2008|agency=Associated Press|authorlink=Associated Press|date=July 21, 2008|work=CNN.com|quote=Leno's last show was Friday, May 29, and O'Brien started the following Monday, June 1, NBC executives told a Television Critics Association meeting Monday. |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080724101827/http://www.cnn.com/2008/SHOWBIZ/TV/07/21/tv.nbc.tonight.ap/index.html |archivedate = July 24, 2008}} Jay Leno's new show, titled ''The Jay Leno Show'', debuted on September 14, 2009. It was announced at the [[Television Critics Association]] summer press tour that it would feature one or two celebrities, the occasional musical guest, and keep the popular "Headlines" segments, which would air near the end of the show. First guests included [[Jerry Seinfeld]], [[Oprah Winfrey]] (via satellite), and a short sit-down with [[Kanye West]] discussing his controversy at the [[2009 MTV Video Music Awards]], which had occurred the night before.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshark.com/read/?art=arc3888|title=Pop Minute - Jay Leno Reveals What To Expect From His New Primetime Show|work=tvshark.com}} ===Timeslot conflict and return to ''The Tonight Show''=== {{wikinews|US TV host Conan O'Brien rejects NBC's offer to switch his show's time slot}} {{main article|2010 Tonight Show conflict}} In their new roles, neither O'Brien nor Leno succeeded in delivering the viewing audiences the network anticipated. On January 7, 2010, multiple media outlets reported that beginning March 1, 2010, Jay Leno would move from his 10 p.m. weeknight time slot to 11:35 p.m., due to a combination of pressure from local affiliates whose newscasts were suffering, and both Leno's and O'Brien's poor ratings.{{cite news| url= http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/entertainmentnewsbuzz/2010/01/future-for-nbcs-the-jay-leno-show-is-up-in-the-air.html |title= Future For NBC's Tonight Show Up In The Air| work= [[Los Angeles Times]]'' blog''| date= January 2010| access-date= }}{{cite news| url= http://www.accesshollywood.com/articles/jay-leno-heading-back-to-late-night-conan-obrien-weighing-options-80698/ | website= accesshollywood.com| title= Jay Leno Heading Back To Late Night, Conan O’Brien Weighing Options| date= January 8, 2010| access-date= January 9, 2017}} Leno's show would be shortened from an hour to 30 minutes. All NBC late night programming would be preempted by the [[2010 Winter Olympics]] between February 15 and 26. This would move ''The Tonight Show'' to 12:05 a.m., a post-midnight timeslot for the first time in its history. O'Brien's contract stipulated that NBC could move the show back to 12:05 a.m. without penalty (a clause put in primarily to accommodate sports preemptions).{{cite news| authorlink= Nikki Finke| last= Finke| first= Nikki| date= January 7, 2010| work= Deadline.com | url= http://www.deadline.com/hollywood/nbc-indicates-changes-coming-to-jay-leno-show-due-to-affiliate-issues/ |title= NBC ON THE HOT SEAT: Will It Be Jay AND Conan In Late Night? What's The Reason For Leno's Anti-NBC Monologue Tonight?| access-date= January 9, 2010}} On January 10, NBC confirmed that they would move Jay Leno out of primetime as of February 12 and intended to move him to late night as soon as possible.{{cite web|url=http://www.thrfeed.com/2010/01/nbc-press-tour-executive-session-live-blog.html |title=NBC confirms move of 'Leno Show' | website= thrfeed.com |agency= Television Critics Association| date= January 10, 2010| author1= [Unknown]| first2= Nellie| last2= Andreeva| accessdate=2015-06-26 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100112215828/http://www.thrfeed.com/2010/01/nbc-press-tour-executive-session-live-blog.html |archivedate=January 12, 2010 |df=mdy }}{{cite news| url= http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/01/07/update-nbc-plans-leno-at-1130-conan-at-12/ | title= Update: NBC Plans Leno at 11:30, Conan at 12| work= [[The New York Times]]'' blog''| date= January 7, 2010}} [[TMZ.com|TMZ]] reported that O'Brien was given no advance notice of this change, and that NBC offered him two choices: an hour-long 12:05am time slot, or the option to leave the network.{{cite news| url= http://www.tmz.com/2010/01/08/conan-obrien-jay-leno-nbc-tonight-show/ |title= NBC to Conan O'Brien – The Choice Is Yours| work= [[TMZ.com]]| date= January 8, 2010}} On January 12, O'Brien issued a press release that stated he would not continue with ''Tonight'' if it moved to a 12:05 a.m. time slot,{{cite news| url= http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/34827830/ns/entertainment-television |title= Conan Won't Do 'The Tonight Show' Following Leno| website= [[MSNBC]].com| date= January 12, 2010}} saying, "I believe that delaying ''The Tonight Show'' into the next day to accommodate another comedy program will seriously damage what I consider to be the greatest franchise in the history of broadcasting. ''The Tonight Show'' at 12:05 simply isn't ''The Tonight Show.''" On January 21, it was announced that NBC had struck a deal with O'Brien. It was decided that O'Brien would leave ''The Tonight Show''. The deal was made that O'Brien would receive a $33 million payout and that his staff of almost 200 would receive $12 million in the departure. O'Brien's final episode aired on Friday, January 22, 2010.{{cite web| first= Robert| last= Seidman| url= http://tvbythenumbers.com/2010/01/21/nbc-announces-that-jay-leno-will-return-to-host-the-tonight-show-beginning-march-1/39671 |title= NBC Announces That Jay Leno Will Return To Host 'The Tonight Show' Beginning March 1| website= tvbythenumbers.com| date= January 21, 2010}}{{cite news| url= http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-01-21/conan-o-brien-signs-accord-to-exit-tonight-show-nbc-says.html |title= NBC Universal Confirms Conan O’Brien Exit Deal Signed| publisher= [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]| work= [[Business Week]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100123091934/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-01-21/conan-o-brien-signs-accord-to-exit-tonight-show-nbc-says.html |archivedate=January 23, 2010| deadurl= yes }}{{cite news| agency=Associated Press |url=http://www.cbc.ca/arts/story/2010/01/21/conan-deal-nbc.html? |title=Conan O'Brien, NBC reach deal |date= January 21, 2010 |publisher=cbc.ca |accessdate=January 16, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100125034959/http://www.cbc.ca/arts/story/2010/01/21/conan-deal-nbc.html |archivedate=January 25, 2010 }} Leno returned as host of ''The Tonight Show'' following the [[2010 Winter Olympics]] on March 1, 2010. On July 1, 2010, ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' reported that total viewership for Jay Leno's ''Tonight Show'' had dropped from 5 million to 4 million for the second quarter of 2010, compared to the same period in 2009. Although this represented the lowest second-quarter ratings for the show since 1992, ''Tonight'' was still the most-watched late night program, ahead of [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''[[Nightline]]'' (3.7 million) and ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' (3.3 million).{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118021316.html?categoryid=14&cs=1|title='Kimmel,' 'Nightline' show demo increase |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=July 1, 2010 | first=Stuart | last=Levine}}{{cite news|work=The Daily Beast |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2010-10-24/jay-lenos-sinking-tonight-show-ratings-will-conan-obrien-get-the-last-laugh/|accessdate=October 26, 2010|title=Comedians Laugh as Leno Sinks|date=October 24, 2010|first=Gina|last=Piccalo}} ===Announcement of successor=== On April 3, 2013, NBC announced that Leno would leave ''The Tonight Show'' in spring 2014, with [[Jimmy Fallon]] as his designated successor.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/tv-column/post/its-official-jimmy-fallon-to-replace-jay-leno-on-the-tonight-show/2013/04/03/3ec85446-9c7e-11e2-9a79-eb5280c81c63_blog.html|title=It's official: Jimmy Fallon to replace Jay Leno on ‘The Tonight Show’|first=Lisa|last=de Moraes|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=April 3, 2013|accessdate=April 3, 2013}} Leno sang the "[[Tonight (1956 song)|Tonight]]"'s parody of ''Tonight Show'' with Fallon. Leno's final show as the host of the Tonight Show was on February 6, 2014 with his final guest [[Billy Crystal]] and musical guest [[Garth Brooks]], along with a few surprise guests, including [[Jack Black]], [[Kim Kardashian]], [[Jim Parsons]], [[Sheryl Crow]], [[Chris Paul]], [[Carol Burnett]], and [[Oprah Winfrey]]. ===After ''The Tonight Show''=== Leno has maintained an active schedule as a touring stand-up comedian appearing in, on average, 200 live performances a year in venues across the United States and Canada{{cite news|title=5 Reasons We Love Jay Leno On The Comedian's 65th Birthday|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/04/28/jay-leno-birthday_n_7153638.html|accessdate=May 21, 2015|work=Huffington Post|date=April 28, 2015}} as well as charity events and [[USO]] tours.{{cite news|title=Jay Leno: I Miss The Tonight Show – But Jimmy Fallon Is 'Terrific'|url=http://www.people.com/article/jay-leno-approves-jimmy-fallon-tonight-show|accessdate=May 21, 2015|work=People|date=November 30, 2014}} He has also made appearances on his successor's ''[[Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon]]''{{cite news|title=Jay Leno Mocks Jimmy Fallon During 'Tonight Show' Return|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/jay-leno-mocks-jimmy-fallon-747617|accessdate=May 21, 2015|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=November 7, 2014}} and on ''[[Late Night with Seth Meyers]]'',{{cite news|title=Jay Leno Thinks College Students Have ‘No Idea What Racism Is’|url=http://www.thewrap.com/jay-leno-racism-college-kids-so-politically-correct-seth-meyers/|accessdate=May 21, 2015|work=The Wrap|date=March 20, 2015}}{{cite news|title=araji P. Henson, Jay Leno, Will Forte Angrily Swipe Desks|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/taraji-p-henson-jay-leno-796978|accessdate=May 21, 2015|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=May 19, 2015}} as well as being a guest on the finale of ''[[The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson]]'' and doing a cameo drilling and torturing [[James Corden]] in a [[boot camp (correctional)|boot camp]] for talk show hosts on the premiere of ''[[The Late Late Show with James Corden]]''.{{cite news|title=James Corden Gets Punched by Jay Leno in Star-Studded 'Late Late Show' Debut|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/late-late-show-james-corden-783868|accessdate=May 21, 2015|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=March 23, 2015}} He declined an invitation to appear on ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' despite speculation he would make an appearance on the show's finale.{{cite news|title=David Letterman vs. Jay Leno: Why did Dave get the finale love denied Jay?|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-david-letterman-vs-jay-leno-who-got-more-finale-love-and-why-20150520-story.html|accessdate=May 21, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=May 21, 2015}} Leno has also hosted an hour long ''[[Jay Leno's Garage]]'' special on [[CNBC]],{{cite news|title=Late-Night Legend Jay Leno Drives to CNBC Primetime|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/102089424|accessdate=May 21, 2015|work=CNBC (News Release)|date=October 14, 2014}} and the show has aired as a primetime series on the cable channel since 2015.{{cite news|title=It's Official: Jay Leno Hosting Primetime CNBC Series|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/official-jay-leno-hosting-primetime-740970|accessdate=May 21, 2015|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=October 14, 2014}} ==Public image== ===Criticism of Leno=== [[File:Jaylenocropped.jpg|right|thumb|Leno on ''The Tonight Show'' in 2005]] Leno has faced heated criticism and some negative publicity for his perceived role in the [[2010 Tonight Show conflict|2010 ''Tonight Show'' conflict]].[https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2010/01/15/why-some-comics-arent-laughing-at-jay-leno-essay/ "Why Some Comics Aren’t Laughing at Jay Leno"]. ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''{{cite news|last=Barnhart |first=Aaron |url=http://www.kansascity.com/238/story/1691791.html |title=Jay Leno is Mr. Nice Guy no more – but was he ever? |date=January 18, 2010 |work=[[The Kansas City Star]] |accessdate=January 16, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100121012846/http://www.kansascity.com/238/story/1691791.html |archivedate=January 21, 2010 }} Critics have pointed to a 2004 ''Tonight Show'' clip, in which Leno said he would allow O'Brien to take over without incident.[http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/285694 "Jay Leno in 2004: 'In '09, Conan, it's yours{{'"}}]. ''Digital Journal'' At the time, Leno stated he did not want O'Brien to leave for a competing network, adding, "I'll be 59 when [the switch occurs], that's five years from now. There's really only one person who could have done this into his 60s, and that was [[Johnny Carson]]; I think it's fair to say I'm no Johnny Carson." Leno also described ''The Tonight Show'' as a [[dynasty]], saying, "You hold it and hand it off to the next person. And I don't want to see all the fighting." At the end of the segment, he said, "Conan, it's yours! See you in five years, buddy!"[http://www.funnyordie.com/videos/6d1caacad1/jay-s-2004-announcement "2004 Tonight Show Clip: 'Conan, It's yours!{{'"}}] [[Funny or Die]]. [[Rosie O'Donnell]] was among O'Brien's most vocal and vehement supporters,{{cite web|url=http://blog.zap2it.com/thedishrag/2010/01/rosie-odonnell-is-on-team-conan.html|title=Rosie O'Donnell is on Team Conan|publisher=[[Zap2it]]|date=January 14, 2010|author=Porter, Rick|accessdate=January 15, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100118084613/http://blog.zap2it.com/thedishrag/2010/01/rosie-odonnell-is-on-team-conan.html|archivedate=January 18, 2010|df=mdy-all}}[http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/2010/01/14/2010-01-14_rosie_odonnell_to_jay_leno_step_aside_and_let_conan_obrien_have_tonight_show.html "Rosie O'Donnell, Jimmy Kimmel slam Jay Leno over ''Tonight Show'' battle"]. ''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]'' (New York). calling Leno a "bully" and his actions "classless and kind of career-defining".[http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2010/01/rosie_odonnell_has_more_to_say.html#ixzz0dIY0bSPJ "Rosie O'Donnell Has More to Say About Jay Leno"]. ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' Bill Zehme, the co-author of Leno's autobiography ''Leading with My Chin'', told the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', "The thing Leno should do is walk, period. He's got everything to lose in terms of public popularity by going back. People will look at him differently. He'll be viewed as the bad guy."[http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-et-leno-backlash16-2010jan16,0,4645138.story?page=2 "Taking on America's 'nice guy{{'"}}]. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. p. 2. [[Howard Stern]] has also been a harsh critic of Leno before and following his ''Tonight Show'' timeslot change announcement;[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pZ2fZH2XqNw&feature=related "Rosie O'Donnell Slams Jay Leno (Part 1 of 2)"]; [[YouTube]]; January 14, 2010 Stern appeared on ''Late Night with Conan O'Brien'' in 2006, and told O'Brien that he felt it was unlikely that Leno would ever willingly give up ''The Tonight Show'' to anyone.[http://talkshownews.interbridge.com/2010/01/howard-stern-to-conan-in-2006-i-dont.html "Howard Stern to Conan in 2006: 'I don't see this guy leaving"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100221232040/http://talkshownews.interbridge.com/2010/01/howard-stern-to-conan-in-2006-i-dont.html |date=February 21, 2010 }} Talk Show News; January 15, 2010 During the conflict, Stern made many negative remarks directed at Leno while on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]''.{{cite web|last1=FISHER|first1=LUCHINA|title=Howard Stern Gets in Another Dig at Leno|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/story?id=7793427|website=ABC News|accessdate=30 June 2017}} In addition to criticism about his handling of the timeslot conflict, Leno has also been criticized for the perceived change in the content of his monologues from his previous stand-up material. Actor and comedian [[Patton Oswalt]] was among the celebrities who openly voiced disappointment with Leno, saying, "Comedians who don't like Jay Leno now, and I'm one of them, we're not like, 'Jay Leno sucks'; it's that we're so hurt and disappointed that one of the best comedians of our generation... willfully has shut the switch off."[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/01/11/patton-oswalt-weighs-in-o_n_419015.html "Patton Oswalt: Jay Leno Is Like Nixon, I Don't Like Him"]. ''[[The Huffington Post]]''. ===Support for Leno=== [[NBC Sports]] chairman and former ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' producer [[Dick Ebersol]] spoke out against all who had mocked Leno, calling them "chicken-hearted and gutless".[http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-et-leno-backlash16-2010jan16,0,4645138.story "Taking on America's 'nice guy{{'"}}]. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. Jeff Gaspin, then chairman of NBC Universal Television Entertainment, also defended Leno, saying, "This has definitely crossed the line. Jay Leno is the consummate professional and one of the hardest-working people in television. It's a shame that he's being pulled into this." Fellow comedians [[Paul Reiser]], [[Jerry Seinfeld]] and [[Jim Norton (American comedian)|Jim Norton]] (a frequent contributor to ''The Tonight Show'') also voiced support for Leno.[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/paul-reiser/a-teachable-leno-moment_b_418197.html "Paul Reiser: A Teachable Moment"]. ''[[The Huffington Post]]''.[http://www.thewrap.com/ind-column/seinfeld-jay-conan-debacle-i-cant-blame-nbc-12758 "Seinfeld on Jay-Conan Debacle: 'I Can't Blame NBC{{'"}}]. ''The Wrap''.{{cite news| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/videos/comedian-defends-lenos-return/ | title=Comedian Defends Leno's Return | work=CBS News}} Responding to the mounting criticism, Leno said that NBC had assured him that O'Brien was willing to accept the proposed arrangement and that they would not let either host out of his contract.[http://www.eonline.com/uberblog/b162674_jay_tries_make_nice_conan_rallies_troops.html "Jay Leno Tries to Make Nice, While Conan Rallies the Troops"]. ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''. Leno also said that the situation was "all business", and that all of the decisions were made by NBC. He appeared on the January 28, 2010, episode of ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'' in an attempt to repair some of the damage done to his public image.{{cite news|last=Marikar|first=Sheila|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/jay-leno-tells-oprah-winfrey-conan-obriens-tonight/story?id=9687814|title=Jay Leno Tells Oprah Winfrey Conan O'Brien's Exit Wasn't His Fault|date=January 28, 2009|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=January 16, 2013}} ==Influences== Leno's biggest influence and his mentor was [[Johnny Carson]]. Other comedians that influenced Leno were [[Robert Klein]], [[Alan King (comedian)|Alan King]], [[David Brenner]], [[Mort Sahl]], [[George Carlin]],{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,20208460,00.html?xid=rss-fullcontentcnn |title=Carlin Remembered: He Helped Other Comics with Drug Problems |publisher=Time Inc. |work=People |author1=Breuer, Howard |author2=Stephen M, Silverman |date=June 24, 2008 |accessdate=June 24, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012122818/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,20208460,00.html?xid=rss-fullcontentcnn |archivedate=October 12, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} [[Don Rickles]],https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jay-leno-longtime-tonight-show-431252 [[Bob Newhart]],http://flavorwire.com/168686/required-listening-10-influential-comedy-albums and [[Rodney Dangerfield]].{{Citation|last=The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon|title=Jay Leno Made a Dying Rodney Dangerfield Laugh|date=2017-04-07|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k0wNKXKsvQg|accessdate=2018-02-09}} Comedians that were influenced by Leno include: [[Dennis Miller]]James Hirsen, [http://archive.newsmax.com/archives/articles/2004/2/4/165208.shtml Dennis Miller: Why I 'Ascended' to the Right], NewsMax.com, February 5, 2004. and [[Jerry Seinfeld]].{{Cite episode|title=Jay Leno: Comedy Is A Concealed Weapon|episode-link=|url=|access-date=|series=Comedians In Cars Getting Coffee|series-link=|last=Seinfeld|first=Jerry|network=|station=|date=|season=3|series-no=|number=3|minutes=5:59|time=|transcript=|transcript-url=|quote="Ya know, Jay, when I met you in the 70's, and I used to come to your house every night (we'd always hang out), you formed my whole professional attitude as a young man, and I always tell people that I learned comedy from Jay."|language=}} ==Personal life== [[File:Obama and Leno.jpg|thumb|Leno with President [[Barack Obama]] in March 2009]] Leno has been married to [[Mavis Leno]] since 1980; the couple have no children, by mutual agreement.{{cite web|url = http://www.whoswhoinamerica.com/jay_leno/talk_show_host_comedian_writer/occ28/5463136|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090507103811/http://www.whoswhoinamerica.com/jay_leno/talk_show_host_comedian_writer/occ28/5463136|dead-url = yes|archive-date = 2009-05-07|title = Jay Leno|work = Who's Who in America|publisher = Marquis}} In 1993, during his first season as host of ''The Tonight Show'', Leno's mother died at the age of 82 and in the following year, his father died at the age of 84.{{cite news|title=Jay Leno's Eulogy Does His Dad Proud| url= http://articles.latimes.com/1994-08-29/entertainment/ca-32548_1_jay-leno|work=Los Angeles Times|date=August 29, 1994| accessdate= February 8, 2014|first=Howard|last=Rosenberg}} Leno's older brother Patrick Leno, a [[Vietnam War|Vietnam]] veteran and graduate of [[Yale Law School]], died in 2002 at the age of 62 as a result of complications from cancer.{{cite news |title= Pushed From Late Night, Leno Is Set for Prime Time|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/12/arts/television/12leno.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 | work= The New York Times|date=September 11, 2009|accessdate=February 8, 2014 |first= Bill| last= Carter}} He is known for his prominent jaw, which has been described as [[Prognathism#Mandibular prognathism (progenism)|mandibular prognathism]].{{cite journal|doi = 10.1034/j.1399-0004.1998.5440404.x|last = Chudley|first = A.E.|title = Genetic landmarks through philately – The Habsburg jaw|journal = Clinical Genetics|volume = 54|issue = 4|pages = 283–284|date=October 1998|pmid = 9831338}} In the book ''Leading with My Chin'', he stated that he is aware of surgery that could reset his mandible, but does not wish to endure a prolonged healing period with his jaws wired shut. Leno is [[Dyslexia|dyslexic]].Carter, Bill. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/12/arts/television/12leno.html Pushed From Late Night, Leno Is Set for Prime Time]" ''The New York Times'', September 12, 2009. He claims to only need four to five hours of sleep each night.{{cite web| first= Mike| last= McLeod| url= http://www.go-star.com/antiquing/leno.htm| title= The Celebrity Collector: Jay Leno – The Tonight Show's $1 Billion Man Collects Cars and Motorcycles| website= go-star.com| publisher= Norton Printing and Publishing, Inc.| access-date= January 9, 2017}} Leno [[Teetotalism|does not drink]] or [[smoking|smoke]], nor does he [[Gambling|gamble]].{{cite web| work= Nevada Magazine | url= http://www.nevadamagazine.com/index.php/issues/read/classic_cars_and_comedy/ |deadurl= yes| title= Classic cars and comedy: Jay Leno talks about Nevada moments and his passion for cars| first= Ann| last= Henderson| date= July–August 2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110505192652/http://www.nevadamagazine.com/index.php/issues/read/classic_cars_and_comedy/ |archivedate= May 5, 2011 }} He spends most of his free time visiting car collections or working in his private garage. Leno has claimed that he has not spent any of the money that he earned from ''The Tonight Show''. Instead, he lives off his money from his stand-up routines.{{cite web|url= http://parade.com/49910/jayleno/jay-leno-persistance-pays-off/ |title= Jay Leno|first= Jay |last= Leno|work= [[Parade (magazine)|Parade]] | date= September 6, 2009| access-date= January 9, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/the-12-most-frugal-celebrities-184410272.html|title=The 12 Most Frugal Celebrities |first= Kirsten| last=Acuna| website= finance.yahoo.com |publisher=[[Business Insider]]|date=March 8, 2013|accessdate=April 3, 2013}} Leno reportedly earned $32 million in 2005.{{cite news| url= https://www.forbes.com/lists/2006/53/207B.html |work= [[Forbes]]| title= The Top 100 Celebrities: Jay Leno: Talking head| date= 2006| access-date= January 9, 2017}} In 2014, he received an [[Honorary degree|Honorary]] [[Doctor of Humane Letters]] degree from [[Emerson College]] where he also delivered the [[Commencement speech]]. http://www.emerson.edu/videos/jay-leno-2014-emerson-college-commencement-address ===Charity=== In 2001, along with his wife, he donated $100,000 to the [[Feminist Majority Foundation]]'s campaign to stop [[gender apartheid]] in Afghanistan, to educate the public regarding the plight of women in Afghanistan under [[Taliban]] rule.
